arch:property.oc:show_val: Pit located in the northeast corner of the trench. Medium sized dark brown clay clumps with ash deposits. Partially (3/4) sealed by a 1cm thick hardened/compacted mud layer that is possibly mud plaster, and two separate plaster layers that were slightly burned and roughly 1-2 cm thick. Pit is lined by a single row of burnt mud bricks averaging 25cm in width by 40cm in length. In northern and western section profile inside pit a black 2-5 cm thick ash layer is visible marking a subdivision within the pit apart from the three layers that sealed the pit on top. Another layer visible in this western section is a surface of flat-lying pot sherds that runs below fill 7214. Note: this locus was stopped though it is possible that the actual pit does continue further (i.e. it may be deeper than the stated elevations)
poor sorting, angular medium clay matrix

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

arch:property.oc:show_val: surface with flat-lying pot sherds visible in west section running below fill 7214

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area F / Trench 7 / Locus 7181 (Locus)
